qas.question: In contrast to large LD disks, what is the size of a standard CD?
What were CD size "single"-style discs called that were compatible with LaserDisc players?

answers.text: CD Video (CD-V) discs, and Video Single Discs (VSD)

qas.question: How much video content could be stored on a CD-V disk?

answers.text: up to five minutes of analog LaserDisc-type video content

qas.question: What were CD-V's video capacities usually used for?
Which artist released a music video and three audio tracks on CD-V in 1989?

context: There were also <a0_0>12 cm (4.7 in)<a0_0/> (CD size) "single"-style discs produced that were playable on LaserDisc players. These were referred to as <a1_0>CD Video (CD-V) discs, and Video Single Discs (VSD)<a1_0/>. A CD-V carried <a2_0>up to five minutes of analog LaserDisc-type video content<a2_0/> (usually a <a3_0>music video<a3_0/>), as well as up to 20 minutes of digital audio CD tracks. The original 1989 release of <a4_0>David Bowie<a4_0/>'s retrospective Sound + Vision CD box set prominently featured a CD-V video of Ashes to Ashes, and standalone promo CD-Vs featured the video, plus three audio tracks: "John, I'm Only Dancing", "Changes", and "The Supermen".
